text: Patient: Yeah. (Pause) Doctor: Well, you folks let’s do this, okay? I -- I’m gonna put the prescription into the pharmacy here, and they’re gonna start checking as to how much it’s gonna cost you. You may say that we don’t have a prescription plan or it’s too expensive, and I can’t do it for that reason. It may be that we get through that and the door’s still open for the study because you can afford it and we can get started. Okay? But you guys have to talk about it as a family. You’ve got the paperwork to read. You can go through it, discuss it. You know, okay, this would mean that we’re gonna have to commit to going down to Baltimore every other week this time, do some more bloodwork. These are the things that I worry about. Yeah, we’re all good for that. Okay? Because you’re not on the study until you meet again with us, that your PSA is rising on the enzalutamide Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So we have to get the enzalutamide started (Pause) Patient: Okay. Okay. Lemme just, so the enzalutamide, the Xtandi, okay. Doctor: That’s all we’re going to start now, and you have to get worse on it to be able to be eligible for the study. (Pause15sec) Patient: Well. We would start first with the Xtandi. I have to – the disease has to progress some more – Doctor: Uh, by PSA only. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: I don’t think you’re gonna need new scans, but that maybe sort of something down the road, but I think you, you really just have to have a rising PSA on the enzalutamide, and then we have to repeat that ARV seven. It has to be positive on enzalutamide, and then you can go onto the study. (Pause) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So, we can follow up that you can afford it. If you want it, then you have to decide, “Okay, I’m gonna take it.” With the idea that you’re going towards this, and maybe about a thirteen percent chance that the PSA will drop just because we added back the Xtandi. Okay?

text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: that’s not uh virus-related but drug related. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: There’s other parts of the body. Any part of your body could get one of these “-itises” —pneumonitis, hepatitis, colitis. So we’re tuned to listen to you and let you, teach you how to tell us right away if there is something going on and then we have to judge fast where we think worried/not worried. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: That’s experimental; we don’t know what the real benefit to someone like you is. We can’t tell you we’re going to make you live longer. Family Member: Mm, hmn. Doctor: But that would be potentially something you could participate in. Right now I would be a little bit worried about putting you on it with these gasping things that I can’t explain- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: because it might affect our ability to get the therapy in. Uhm, we have another study which I, uh - Transformer - we have a first-in-human study of a drug that comes from plum seeds. In laboratory studies it looks like it can attack and kill prostate cancer cells. So this is a study where we’re looking at a drug that now is in I.V. form to see how often does it affect the PSA, how often do you get side effects that we can’t give it to you. So it’s more about the side effects and whether it helps you or not. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Some of the data says that it could help you, but we don’t know. We’ve never given it to enough men. We treat a number of men and if they do okay, then we go to a higher dose.

text: Patient: Right, right, right. Doctor: So um I I think the time has come uh to uh stop this study and potentially switch gears. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um there’s two primary reasons for that. One is um PSA level has now increased by more than double - Patient: Yes. Doctor: - compared to the first one; call that the baseline number. So the trial was designed in such a way - because we don’t want to be giving people an experimental therapy and harming them by delaying improving therapy. So the trial was designed in such a way that it was built with a safety check. And the safety check is if the PSA goes up by twofold, then, in other words, a one hundred percent increase from baseline, then patient will come off study. So you have now crossed that threshold. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: A month ago, you hadn’t and now you’ve you’ve crossed that number which I think was twenty-six point seven. So you’re two points above that. The second reason is um having to do with your scans. We have the results of your bone scan and your um CAT scan. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The um the bone scan looks completely unchanged, in other words normal. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we don’t think there is any evidence or hint that there could be prostate cancer in the bone. And that is really the most important thing; so I wanted to say that first. The second one is the CAT scan. So on the CAT scan, you have a lymph node inside your abdomen - Patient: Okay.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
